awd_titl_txt: Cosmic Ray Feedback in a Multi-Phase Medium
awd_abstract_narration:
Over cosmic time, galaxies grow by acquiring gas and turning it into stars. Models of the growth of galaxies need to deal with the influence of star formation and evolution on the rate at which gas is then cooled and turned into more stars, in a process known as 'feedback'. This project will develop better models on the role that high-energy particles known as cosmic rays play in feedback. These models will then be made available to astrophysicists to better model galaxy growth.

The proposed project will develop 'small-scale physics' models of how cosmic rays interact with cold and warm gas in the circumgalactic medium. They will look at a number of interactions involving cosmic rays, including turbulence, thermal instabilities, and cloud entrainment. This physics will then be incorporated in MHD codes for modeling feedback in galaxies.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This award funded work to study the impact of cosmic rays on cold gas, in a multi-phase setting. It resulted in 8 published papers. This includes work on cosmic ray modified shocks, the cosmic ray acoustic instability, the impact of cosmic rays on thermal and hydrostatic stability in galaxy halos, the turbulent reacceleration of cosmic rays, and cosmic ray damping of compressive turbulence, as well as closely related work on multi-phase gas (cooling driven coagulation and the accretion braking of cold gas), and a review of key physical processes in the circumgalactic medium. Research findings from this grant were widely disseminated at numerous conferences and colloquia. The grant enabled the training of two graduate students (one wholly and one partially supported by the grant), who have received their PhDs and moved on to postdocs at University of Colorado, Boulder and the Center for Computational Astrophysics respectively. In addition, it funded a postdoc partially supported by this grant, and enabled close collaboration with a KITP postdoc. Two undergraduates were mentored in year old research projects, jointly between the PI and a postdoc. In addition, the two graduate students supported by this grant designed and taught a 5 week course for high school students "Plasma: the fourth state of matter" with 64% URM, 80% female participation under the School of Scientific Thought, in partnership with the Early Academic Outreach Program. This is a state-wide program for students at under-privileged high schools which aim to supply them with academic role models and prepare them for admission to University of California or California State University.
